ALLEGATION: Youth A and Youth B engaged in consensual sexual activity.
INVESTIGATION:
I spoke to DHHS Social Service Worker on 12/6/21. Allegation and scheduling were
discussed.
I reviewed the following documents throughout the course of the investigation:
 Sexual Acting Out Precaution (SAO) Residential Round Sheet:
 Observation Process (level of Monitoring) Policy:
 Staff schedule

 Incident reports (2)
I reviewed the Incident reports.
Youth B’s Incident Report was dated 11/30/21: The therapist was notified on November
30, 2021 that the youth had consensual sexual interactions. Youth B reported he
“licked” Youth A’s penis in the corner of his room for 5-10 seconds. The second incident
Youth B reported he “licked” Youth A’s penis for 5-10 seconds in the corner of the
bedroom. Youth B reported a third incident occurred where Youth A had his pants
pulled down in the corner of the bedroom and asked him (Youth B) to “anally penetrate”
him. Youth B reported he refused to comply. Safety plan was put into place: Youth A
was placed in a different room and placed on social isolation (removal from the group).
Youth A’s Incident Report was dated 12/1/21: The incidents occurred sometime
between 11/4-11/11/21. Youth A reported he and another resident (Youth B) “acted out
on 3 occasions”. Youth A reported it happened while he was on individual focus. Youth
A reported it happened in the bedroom corner and he reported Staff 1 may have been at
the door for one of the three occasions. The other two times Youth B “licked his penis”
for 5-10 seconds.
Observation of bedroom: I observed the bedroom where the alleged incidents
occurred. The bedroom has a direct line of sight from the door entrance to all three
beds. All three beds are sequentially after each other. Once you enter the bedroom,
there is a locked bathroom/shower to the left. Then a few steps further the room opens
up and the beds are one after another. To the left is a corner that is not seen if you
would be standing at the entrance of the bedroom. Across from the beds are storage
units. There is a security mirror in the top right corner of the room so that there are no
blind spots in the room.
Interview of Youth A
DHHS Social Service Worker interviewed Youth A at Wayne County Juvenile Detention
Center on 12/13/21. Youth A reported peers were never allowed to be alone together at
the facility nor were they allowed to talk in their bedrooms. Youth A reported he
disobeyed these rules with his peer Youth B. Youth A reported there were 3-4 incidents
where he broke these rules. The first incident was when Youth B “exposed” himself to
Youth A. The second and third time was “mutual fondling”. Youth A reported they
mutually touched each other’s penis. The fourth time was when there was mutually
fondled each other’s penis and gave each other “oral”. Youth A reported that none of
the incidents were longer than a minute and a half long and happened over a two-week
time frame. Youth A reported he was not sure where the staff were when it happened,
but they are supposed to be at the door watching them. Youth A reported that Staff 1
was there one of the times.
All of the following interviews were conducted with DHHS Social Service Worker.

Interview Youth B
Youth B reported that the rules of the bedroom are as follows: two youth are not allowed
to be by the cubicles together, during wake-up, there is one youth in the hallway, one in
the bathroom and one at their bed. Youth B reported that they (Youth A and Youth B)
were able to engage in sexual activity due to them not following the rules. Youth B
reported that all three of them would be in the room together even if one of them was
supposed to be out in the hallway. Youth B reported that staff would watch them but not
direct anyone to leave the bedroom. Youth B reported the first incident occurred when
staff (unknown) was at the bedroom door talking to another youth in the hallway. Youth
B reported that Youth A came and sat on his bed and asked if he could give him (Youth
B) “oral”. This exchange was quick. Youth B reported he stated “seriously” and then
they went into the corner of the room and Youth B reported Youth A gave Youth B oral
for about 5-10 seconds. The second incident occurred in the morning as well. Youth A
went into the corner and then Youth B followed and masturbated Youth A for 5-10
seconds and then “licked” his penis. Youth B reported that staff was sitting at the desk
in the hallway but was distracted getting ready for school and talking to the other youth
in the hallway. The third incident occurred when Staff 3 was supervising the youth.
Youth B reported he went with Staff 3 to get his medications and then when he came
back the room light was off and Youth A was in the corner of the bedroom. Youth B
reported that Youth A wanted Youth B to give him “oral” but Youth B declined. Youth B
reported Staff 3 sat at the desk in the hallway.
Interview Administrator 1
We interviewed Administrator 1 on 12/14/21. Administrator 1 reported Youth B is on a
“Sexually Precaution Plan”, (SAO). Administrator 1 reported Youth B is the first bed in
his room. Staff are to have direct line of sight. During school Youth B sits next to a
teacher. Administrator 1 reported Youth B is on SAO due to passing notes or making
sexual comments. Administrator 1 reported Youth B is not an aggressive youth but can
be sneaky. Administrator 1 reported that Youth A has in the past provoked other peers.
Youth A had physically attacked Youth B in the past. Administrator 1 reported Youth A
and Youth B share a bedroom with one other peer. This decision was based on that
Youth A and Youth B do not show any interest in each other as friends or in a sexual
manner. Administrator 1 reported that the youth’s bedroom assignments are decided by
their therapist. Each bed has an “umbrella” alarm system surrounding it. An alarm rings
when a child moves into the boundaries of the alarm system. A child would not be able
to move much in their bed without the alarm sounding off. Administrator 1 reported the
alarms are turned on when the youth go into their bedrooms for the night. Administrator
1 reported that there is 1:6 staffing ratio at sleep time. Administrator 1 reported Youth A
is on an “individual focus”. This means he is removed from the group and placed in his
bedroom so that he can refocus on his treatment. Youth A received all the same
interventions, therapy, and school while in individual focus he was just isolated from the
rest of the peers. This individual focus occurred between 11/4/21-11/11/21.
4

Administrator 1 reported there is not a “wake up” or “shower” policy or procedure
written.
Interview Staff 1
We interviewed Staff 1, direct care worker because Youth A reported she may have
been on duty during one of the alleged incidents. Staff 1 reported she works midnight
shift. Staff 1 reported she is assigned two rooms for a total of six children. Staff 1
reported they turned the alarms for the beds on when it is bedtime. Staff 1 reported the
alarms are very sensitive and will go off sometimes if the youth move slightly in their
beds. Staff 1 reported 6:30am is wake up time for the youth. Staff 1 reported the
following practice for wake-up time: One of the youths wake up and go to the bathroom.
While the first youth is in the bathroom the second youth is woken up and makes his
bed. The third youth is still in in his bed. Once the youth in the bathroom is done, he
then goes into the hallway and the second youth goes into the bathroom and then the
third youth is making his bed. Then the second youth comes out in the hallway and then
the third youth is in the bathroom. No two youth are up and moving around in the
bedroom together at wake-up time. Staff 1 reported she had never seen two of the
youth together in the bedroom and no one has reported any inappropriate behaviors to
her. Staff 1 reported she is constantly redirecting Youth A. Staff 1 was aware of the
backgrounds of the youth she provides care for. Staff 1 did not have any specific
information regarding the alleged incidents.
We interviewed Staff 2, Teacher Assistant. Staff 2 reported Youth A and Youth B do not
get along well. Staff 2 reported that Youth B sits right next to her in class due to Youth B
expressing that he wants to sexually act out (no specific other youth mentioned to act
out with). Staff 2 reported that if they have to go to the bedroom, there is a staff at the
bedroom door and if there are more than one youth in the bedroom, you must visually
see the youth at all times. If anyone communicates while in the bedroom, then all the
youth must come out. Staff 2 reported that Youth A was on “Individual focus” therefore
he was in his bedroom alone. Youth A would be checked on by the supervisor on duty
and the floater. Staff 2 reported she had never seen Youth A and Youth B sexually act
out.
Interview Staff 3
We interviewed Staff 3, direct care worker because Youth B reported Staff 3 was on
duty during the 3rd incident. Staff 3 reported he watches Youth B very closely. Staff 3
reported wake up practice is that there is only youth up at a time. The first youth goes
into the bathroom while the other two youth are in their beds. Once the first youth is
done with the bathroom, he goes into the hallway and then the next youth goes into the
bathroom, while the third youth is still in bed. Staff 3 reported that when the 2nd youth
goes into the bathroom, he allows the first youth to go back into the room to make his
bed. When he completes this task, he then can come back out into the hallway. Staff 3
reported that he wakes Youth B up first and Youth A last. Staff 3 reported there are
5

times that Staff 1 does get distracted and the staff redirect the youth around her to
support her. Staff 3 did not have any specifics regarding the alleged 3rd incident.
I reviewed Youth B’s Sexual Acting Out Precaution (SAO) Residential Round Sheet:
Youth B is listed as having “Sexual Acting Out Precautions” (SAO). His level of monitoring
by staff is to have 15-minute checks but also “direct observation” (line of sight) at all times.
(All youth are required the 15-minute checks, unless more intensive monitoring is
required).
The agency did not have a bathroom or bedroom, or wake-up time policy or
procedure outlined.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4109 Program statement.
(1) An institution shall have and follow a current written
program
statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission,
care, safety, and supervision, methods for addressing
residents' needs, implementation of treatment plans, and
discharge of residents.
ANALYSIS: Staff 1, 3 and Youth A and B consistently described the same
facility’s identified practice/procedure for morning wakeup.
When facility staff adhere to this practice/procedure adequate
supervision is provided to prevent sexual contact as described
in this investigation. Although specific dates were not provided
by Youth A and B both report that facility staff did not adhere to
the identified practice/procedure resulting in their ability to
sexual inappropriate behavior.
The facility has an identified practice/procedure however this
rule requires specific written policies and procedures to provide
for the care and safety and protection of youth.
6

.
TECHNICAL The facility has an acceptable practice/procedure for supervising
ASSISTANCE during wake-up. The facility however must make the
practice/procedure part of the written program policies and
procedures as required by this rule. The facility must also train
staff in the written policy procedure to maintain compliance with
this rule.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Repeat Violation 2022C0325042 (CAP pending)
IV. RECOMMENDATION
A. It is recommended that the license remain unchanged.

sir_summary.summary: Havenwyck Hospital's Impulse Disorder Program failed to prevent multiple incidents of consensual sexual activity between two youths (Youth A and Youth B) in a shared bedroom, which occurred due to staff not following the facility's established wake-up supervision procedure. The investigation found the facility lacked a written policy or procedure for wake-up and bathroom times, violating licensing rules requiring written policies for care, safety, and supervision. Culpability lies with the facility administration for failing to codify and enforce adequate written supervision policies, resulting in a regulatory violation.
